Vitamin D.why: As a 55-year-old male, the user's skin tone (medium) and age may contribute to a reduced ability to synthesize vitamin D from sunlight. Vitamin D plays a crucial role in regulating skin health, and a lack of it has been linked to acne. Given the user's age, sex, and skin tone, a lack of vitamin D could exacerbate acne.
Vitamin D.tip: Spend 10-15 minutes outside during peak sun hours (10am-4pm) to boost vitamin D production.

Zinc.why: Zinc is essential for skin health, and a lack of it can impair wound healing, leading to persistent acne. As a male, the user's sex puts him at a higher risk of zinc imbalances. The user's age and sex also influence his zinc requirements.
Zinc.tip: Include zinc-rich foods in your diet, and consider taking a zinc supplement after consulting a doctor.

Omega-3.why: Omega-3 fatty acids help reduce inflammation, and a lack of them can contribute to acne. As a 55-year-old male, the user's age and sex may affect his omega-3 levels. A diet rich in omega-3s can help alleviate acne symptoms.
Omega-3.tip: Incorporate omega-3 rich foods into your diet, and consider taking a fish oil supplement after consulting a doctor.

Zinc.why: Zinc plays a crucial role in skin health and acne regulation. A lack of zinc can impair wound healing and increase inflammation, exacerbating acne. As a male, the user's zinc needs are higher due to increased sebum production.

Omega-3.why: Omega-3 fatty acids help reduce inflammation and promote healthy skin. A lack of omega-3 can contribute to acne. As a 55-year-old male, the user's skin may benefit from omega-3's anti-inflammatory effects.
